title: HTML Comments
subject: HTML
learning_objectives: Learn the syntax for HTML comments
Learn how to comment out code for debugging
theory:
# HTML Comments Comments are pieces of code that are **ignored by the browser**. They are not displayed on the web page, but they can be seen in the source code. ## Purpose of Comments 1. **Documentation:** Explain complex code to yourself or other developers. 2. **Debugging:** Temporarily hide parts of the code to isolate errors (commenting out). 3. **Reminders:** Leave notes like "TODO: Fix this link". ## Syntax An HTML comment starts with ``. ```html

This is visible.

``` You can comment out multiple lines: ```html ```

examples.code: Welcome
examples.explanation: The text 'Header Section' and the paragraph are hidden. Only 'Welcome' is shown.

common_mistakes.correction: Ensure you close the comment with -->. If you forget, the rest of your page might disappear!
common_mistakes.example:
❌ <!-- This is a comment  (Missing end tag!)
✅ <!-- This is a comment -->

common_mistakes.correction: HTML does not support nested comments. It will break the code.

interview_questions.question: Are HTML comments secure?
interview_questions.answer: No. Comments are not displayed in the browser window, but they are fully visible to anyone who uses 'View Page Source'. Never put passwords or sensitive data in comments.

interview_questions.question: Can you nest HTML comments?
interview_questions.answer: No, nesting comments (placing a comment inside another comment) is invalid and can cause the browser to close the comment early, breaking the page layout.

practice_problems.problem: Add a comment above a heading that says 'Main Title'.

real_world_use_cases.description: In large teams, developers use comments to mark the start and end of major sections (e.g., <!-- Start Navigation --> ... <!-- End Navigation -->).

exam_notes: Invisible to user, visible in source code
summary: Comments allow you to add notes to your HTML code that are ignored by the browser. They are essential for documenting your code and temporarily disabling elements during debugging. Always remember that comments are public in the source code.
